Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as proteinuria, alopecia, acute pericarditis, arthropathy, and neuropsychiatric manifestations including delirium.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD is an autoimmune disorder that may feature a combination of symptoms seen in various diseases including lupus. Patients can exhibit proteinuria, acute pericarditis, arthropathy, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: This inflammatory disease can cause skin rash, muscle weakness, and is associated with systemic symptoms such as arthropathy. Alopecia and proteinuria may accompany due to autoimmune overlap syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.rationale: Scleroderma can lead to systemic symptoms including skin changes like alopecia, kidney involvement manifesting as proteinuria, and occasionally, acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: This chronic inflammatory disorder primarily affects the joints (arthropathy) but can also involve extra-articular manifestations including skin and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. It can involve the skin, joints, and might have systemic manifestations including those affecting the heart and kidney.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: This infection of the heart valves can sometimes lead to renal complications such as proteinuria, skin manifestations, and acute pericarditis; arthralgia and mental status changes could also be present.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA). Vasculitis can affect many organ systems leading to a broad range of symptoms including kidney involvement (proteinuria), joint pains, and occasionally, acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi. Late-stage Lyme can affect the skin, nervous system causing delirium, musculoskeletal system, and occasionally have cardiac involvement.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV infection/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome can present with a wide array of symptoms including kidney involvement (proteinuria), skin manifestations (alopecia through secondary infections or conditions), and less commonly, acute pericarditis.

diagnoses: Phrynoderma (a form of follicular hyperkeratosis due to Vitamin A deficiency)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, though not directly associated with the other symptoms but could be a separate condition or due to systemic disease involvement)

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. It can manifest with symptoms of increased appetite and susceptibility to infections due to a slowed metabolism and weakened immune system.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood glucose levels. Increased appetite is a common symptom due to the body's inability to use glucose properly. Hyperglycemia can also weaken the immune system, making the body more susceptible to infections.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol. It can lead to increased appetite, weakened immune response, and various neurological symptoms, which may sometimes mimic seizures.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues and are characterized by skin hyperelasticity, joint hypermobility, and tissue fragility. Patients may experience various neurologic symptoms including headaches and pseudoseizures.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizures (PNES)
diagnoses.description: Also known as pseudoseizures, they are episodes that resemble epileptic seizures but lack the characteristic electrical discharges seen in epilepsy. They are associated with psychological conditions and may co-occur with other symptoms like headaches due to stress.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions like Crohn's disease or celiac disease can lead to increased appetite due to malabsorption of nutrients, along with a higher susceptibility to infections due to compromised mucosal immunity.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome significantly weakens the immune system, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections. Some treatment regimens or the infection itself can cause increased appetite or metabolic changes.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and tissue damage in affected organs, including joints (leading to hypermobility in some cases), skin, and the neurological system, potentially contributing to headaches and cognitive disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It's also associated with headaches, and although less commonly, an increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Symptoms may include headaches, sleep abnormalities, and a host of neurological complaints, though increased appetite is less commonly reported.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infection due to decreased immunity.
Bone pain due to bone marrow infiltration.
Increased immunoglobulins go along with the disease pathology.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
reasoning: Wheezing due to airway obstruction.
Increased susceptibility to infections like pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
reasoning: Wheezing due to airway hyperresponsiveness.
May lead to increased susceptibility to respiratory infections.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Bronchitis
reasoning: Wheezing and increased susceptibility to respiratory infections.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
reasoning: May present with wheezing due to lung involvement.
Bone pain due to lytic lesions.
Can be associated with hypergammaglobulinemia.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency
reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infection due to inherent immune system deficiency.

diagnoses.name: Bronchiectasis
reasoning: Wheezing and increased susceptibility to infections due to abnormal airway architecture.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
reasoning: Bone pain due to bone marrow infiltration.
Increased susceptibility to infection due to compromised immune function.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infection due to immune system compromise.
Depression due to chronic illness.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
reasoning: Bone pain from bone involvement.
Increased susceptibility to infection due to immune disruption.
Increased immunoglobulins depending on the subtype.

diagnoses: Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
Drug reaction (e.g., to NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors)
Hypotension (including septic, cardiogenic, or due to bleeding)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can lead to hypotension, angioedema, and pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema).

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the adrenal glands produce insufficient amounts of steroid hormones, leading to hypotension, and potentially, abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal Syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting (syncope) that can be accompanied by hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which mast cells accumulate in the skin and/or internal organs, leading to symptoms such as abdominal cramps, angioedema, and pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections, often leading to hypotension and rashes (which might be associated with pruritus).

diagnoses.name: Systemic Capillary Leak Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder characterized by episodes of severe hypotension, hemoconcentration, and hypoalbuminemia without significant albuminuria.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal Allergies
diagnoses.description: Allergic reactions related to certain foods or drugs that can cause abdominal cramps, angioedema, and pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Acute Intermittent Porphyria
diagnoses.description: A rare metabolic disorder that can cause severe abdominal cramps, along with other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of symptoms associated with carcinoid tumors, such as flushing, abdominal cramps, and hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing a range of symptoms including movement, sensory, and cognitive issues.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients, leading to symptoms like paralysis, speech difficulties, and sensory disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances (scintillations) and other neurological symptoms prior to the headache phase.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of stroke-like symptoms such as paralysis and sensory deficits, caused by a temporary decrease in blood supply to part of the brain.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the body's immune system attacks the nerves, leading to muscle weakness, numbness, and tingling sensations.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain or close to the brain, which can cause a variety of symptoms depending on its location, including changes in sensation, movement, and cognitive functions.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes, causing numbness, tingling, and pain, often starting in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from restricted blood flow in the arteries at the base of the brain, leading to symptoms like vertigo, double vision, slurred speech, and swallowing difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the eyes.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A neurological disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control and leading to paralysis.

diagnoses: Metabolic disorders (e.g., hypothyroidism, vitamin B12 deficiency)
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: Discoid rash, synovitis, lymphopenia, and proteinuria are all common manifestations. Lichen planus is not typically associated but could appear concomitantly due to autoimmune dysregulation.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Synovitis is a primary feature. Lichen planus and lymphopenia can occur as extra-articular manifestations. Proteinuria could result from secondary amyloidosis. Discoid rash is not typical but could represent a coexistent condition.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Features overlap with SLE, including lymphopenia and proteinuria. Discoid rash and synovitis suggest an overlap syndrome. Lichen planus is less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Lymphopenia is common, and synovitis can occur in Sjögren's. While discoid rash and proteinuria are less typical, patients can have extensive systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting muscles and skin, it can present with symptoms such as rash (though typically not discoid) and systemic features. Proteinuria may indicate renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: Specific to the renal involvement of SLE, presenting with proteinuria. Other systemic signs like discoid rash and lymphopenia support the diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Undifferentiated Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Presents with various signs and symptoms found in connective tissue diseases including synovitis, rash, and potentially lymphopenia or proteinuria before fully developing into a specific disease.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Synovitis is a hallmark. Lichen planus and the other symptoms are more unusual but can appear due to overlapping autoimmune activities.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.rationale: Lichen planus is sometimes associated. Other symptoms like discoid rash and lymphopenia are less typical, but autoimmune overlap can occur.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis C-related Cryoglobulinemia
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause proteinuria, lymphopenia, and a variety of rashes, although discoid rash is less typical. Hepatitis C can also be associated with lichen planus.

diagnoses: Lupus Erythematosus with Central Nervous System Involvement
Chronic Kidney Disease (related to systemic conditions)
